column11: not colors) are displayed  correctly on the terminal. The way it\'s done now seems to work well under OS X and Linux on all the supported Pythons

column14: but the output still needs to be encoded (somehow) to ensure that unicode works. It\'s quite tricky to solve it universally. Any help appreciated."'

column11: pointed it at the github api and there it is
column12: line for line at your finger tips. What more could you want? Well... if its ok to make one tiny little request.  When making queries with lots of data in the body
column13: like those github datasets
column14: you end up at the bottom of the results completely missing the headers which just flew past and then having tol scroll up every time to get to the part you were mainly interested in.  We could do with a little paging action would you agree? Want some? All yours! =) My contribution and gratitude:  this proposal lets the  $PAGER environment variable be queried for a pager of your choice or we fall back to  . Pipes and redirects are not affected. Streaming directly to pager so no tmp files or any such nonsense. Commit messages have more details. Keep up the good work! =) nJoy!'"

column10: b'b" I see
column11: the problem is that in the loop context HTTPie inherits its (which is redirected). You should be able to work it around by changing HTTPie\'s back to the terminal input ( ):  "'

column10: b'b" Wow. That works.  I had NO idea that the inner statements of a shell loop inherit the stdin of the surrounding loop. Thank you for the help... I\'m not sure I would have found that on my own. (Now I\'m curious why (I\'m assuming all SH derived shells) made that design choice... )"'
b'b" I think there should be an option to disable the reading of that would work everywhere
column11: so I\'m keeping this open and tagging it as a feature."'

column10: b"b' This is very confusing
column11: and goes against httpie being able to work anywhere. Using such a command inside a bash loop is a very common application. Httpie should not complain when  is given and it receives stdin: instead letting  dominate.'"

column10: b"b'  That maybe is intuitive to you
column11: but to many others the exact opposite is far more intuitive. Because tooling should not try to guess
column12: it is far better to raise an error and provide you an escape hatch if you feel you know better
column13: which this does.'"

column12: I do not have the ability to fork and offer a pull request at the moment. Besides
column13: maybe I missed something and this patch is not needed. If this were to be properly included I suspect a  when both foo=bar and data is used. Making the function used to populate  from items smarter would require adding some magic keyword like \'rawdata:=blah\' and ensuring the parser does not attempt to inspect blah at all. This is why I added a data option instead. If this functionality really is missing I can fork and make a proper pull request when time allows. Note my example script at the end makes it look like potentially the data could be read from a file. But I would really like to keep it all contained in the script. However

b'b" For what it\'s worth
column11: I happen to be a user that likes seeing the keys in my JSON output sorted.  My server doesn\'t define an order that it outputs the keys in
column12: and if I\'m looking to see if the key I expect was included in the JSON body or not
column13: it\'s much easier when they\'re sorted.  So I\'d say not to just arbitrarily remove the sorting functionality
column14: but rather make it configurable or toggleable via flag."'

column10: b'b" HTTPie doesn\'t apply gzip compression to uploads.  refers to the accepted _response_ encoding types."'
b"b' Non-conformant Accept header'"
b"b' With the recent fix for #470
column11: HTTPie sends: This header is not quite correct. According to [RFC\\xc2\\xa07231 \\xc2\\xa7\\xc2\\xa05.3.2]url  it says: \\xe2\\x80\\x9cI accept JSON or anything else\\xe2\\x80\\x9d. Because there are no explicit quality values ( ) specified for either media range
column12: they are both assumed to be 1
column13: so and are equally acceptable. should be marked with a lower quality value
column14: for example:  '"

column10: b'b" @vfaronov thanks for the report. I considered including the weight qualifier but then decided against it because it\'s optional and specific media ( ) have  automatically higher priority than ranges ( ):"'
b"b' @jkbrzt The text you quoted defines \\xe2\\x80\\x9cprecedence\\xe2\\x80\\x9d for purposes of the text that follows:Thus
column11: given:  if we consider the media type
column12: the _media range with the highest precedence that matches the type_ is
column13: and its quality value is 1;if we consider the media type
column14: the _media range with the highest precedence that matches the type_ is
column15: and its quality value is also 1. In other words
column16: this \\xe2\\x80\\x9cprecedence\\xe2\\x80\\x9d only tells you how to match a given type to one of the quality values specified in
column17: but does not influence the quality values themselves. That is my reading of the spec.'"

column10: b'b" I would also like to ask to send only.  From the documentation:  (default) Data items from the command line are serialized as a JSON object.   The Content-Type and Accept headers are set to    (if not specified). With the change on #470
column11: it\'s no longer possible to force using config file unless we use sessions."'

column10: b'b" Including with a default q value is indeed meaningless. Note that there is no server requirement to honor the Accept request header field
column11: so a server doesn\'t need to return 406 if it doesn\'t have an representation."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve been down this path as well
column11: @vfaronov is representing a common interpretation. That is
column12: the specificity affects the media type
column13: so a more specific subtype sets precedence over a similarly typed media range. However
column14: once the specificity resolves media types
column15: they are ordered according to quality scores. I believe that this part of the RFC is ambiguous to readers.  In this interpretation
column16: when a server has an internal preference of serving over
column19: is telling the server it has no preference of which media type to respond with (because both media type quality scores are 1.0). This causes non-obvious media type choices when using httpie. Perhaps it helps to see what some browsers set in their headers:  url In that link
column20: Internet Explorer and Edge are the only two browsers that don\'t specify a quality score for media ranges.  You can see this in the Apache documents:  url Apache understands the intention of clients to have be a lower quality score
column21: and thus set that internally  . However
column22: there are servers in the wild that do not follow this interpretation. Thus
column23: it is desirable for httpie to be explicit
column24: and set a quality score that is lower than 1.0 for the wildcard when operating in JSON mode."'

column10: b'b" Another example.  Sending a request with such Accept header to a Rails app
column11: which is serving browsers & API
column12: will always return an HTML response : url As @kjmph said
column13: it\'s because some browsers don\'t set quality score correctly.  We can assume this behavior should be quite common to many other web servers"'
